title: Princess Leah
author: Princess Leah
content: https://bitcointalk.org/index.php?topic=5507048.0 I created this topic to counter that thread in the link above. Well he might be right but it depends on the Cryptocurrency though and to clarify his statement, first off you need to know what an asset means and according to the Oxford dictionary as asset could be classified as a useful or valiable thing or person now this brings us to the conclusion that is Bitcoin a thing? Yes a digital currency, is it useful? Yes it's used for carrying out transactions, does it have value? Yes it does and it's value has increased over time in different circles. Those physical assets (Real estate, precious  metals, oil etc) you just mentioned comes natural and can be regenerated by nature yes owners can use them for different purposes like he stated but then likewise Bitcoin, it's not physical but can be used and is currently used for carrying out transactions and unlike other assets what gives Bitcoin it's value it's the Volatility, so he should stop trying to give people the impression that it's not an asset Bitcoin is a digital asset.

comments.author: _act_
comments.body: If fiat are assets, many cryptocurrencies are assets.But there are two types of assets. Which are appreciative assets and depreciative assets. An asset that its value are reducing are called depreciative assets. Examples are fiat and most altcoins.

comments.author: BitGoba
comments.body: Bitcoin is not an asset; Bitcoin is money. Throughout history, money has taken many forms, but money consistently serves three functional purposes: a store of value, a unit of account, and a medium of exchange.Medium of exchange: People use money to exchange for other goods or services. It is the ultimate good for which any other good or service can be purchased. All products of human labor can be exchanged with money.Unit of account: Money serves as a means of expressing the value of a particular good or service.Store of value: It maintains value over a long period, allowing us to exchange it for goods and services when we need them.

comments.body: I didn't want to reply to this post because it didn't need to be a topic. It can simply be a reply to the topic the OP is referring to but some of the views here are funny. Throughout history, money has taken many forms, but money consistently serves three functional purposes: a store of value, a unit of account, and a medium of exchange.Who has led you people to believe money cannot be an asset? Is it because the value of fiat currencies never appreciate anymore? because they just depreciate? A currency can also be an asset. Gold for example is a currency and it's also an asset. If you hold dollars, pounds, yuan or euros to appreciate so you can sell and make a profit from it then you have made those fiat currencies an asset. It's the same with bitcoin. It's an asset and also a currency. It is mostly used as an asset doesn't mean it is no longer a currency. They are not mutually exclusive, it can be a currency/money and also an asset. It is the most superior form of cryptocurrency. Saying bitcoin is not crypto is like saying the dollar is not fiat. If you want to separate bitcoin from other cryptos then you should use "altcoins".

comments.author: Hatchy
comments.body: Quote from: Ambatman on September 04, 2024, 08:30:46 AMJust like Bitcoin coin is an asset so also is most shitcoins Why? Are shitcoins a thing? Yes they digital currency Are they useful? Yes to scam many of their capital and other extrinsic uses.  I wasn't keen on joining the other discussion over there before now, as the op literally is a shit poster, a hater and someone who doesn't understand what he speaks of... What I think will be best to describe Bitcoin is just very simply as a digital asset. It's not something that can be held or seen but then it retains its value in the physical form.Bitcoin also exhibits characteristics of both money and assets I just wonder why some people keeps making things complicated for them selfs. What distinguish BTC from all other currency or digital asset is that it is decentralized, it isn't controlled by any person or owned by any country. Thats the first fun fact making it an even better asset and form of money. Now, to be considered as money, it should be able to facilitate transactions, and have a standard unit of value.. Bitcoin meets these criteria, serving as a medium of exchange, with its own pricing mechanism and ability to store and retrieve value, despite volatility...as a digital asset, Bitcoin represents unique digital ownership, offering potential value appreciation over time. Again, its total supply is capped at 21 million, giving it the last attribute, scarcityI'm not the type that likes writing a wall of text but I just tried to see how I can use my common knowledge to explain why BTC is both a digital asset, a better form of money, and why it was created as an alternative payments method. Its value changes due to market factors, making it  akin to an asset like gold or stocks, which also fluctuate in value.

comments.author: serjent05
comments.body: Quote from: BitGoba on September 04, 2024, 08:52:50 AMApart from a few superficial similarities, Bitcoin and crypto have nothing in common. Crypto is centrally controlled and created to generate quick profits for its creators or early investors. It relies on strong marketing of lies, deception, and fraud;Please don't get confused.  In terminology, cryptocurrency is a digital currency that uses cryptography for security.[1]  You can read more about cryptocurrency below[1]  and Bitcoin is part of these so called cryptocurrency meaning Bitcoin is under the umbrella of cryptocurrency.  Even if you believe that crypto is not Bitcoin (which is wrong) but altcoin, they still have in common.  They both runs in blockchain, the difference is that some are running in centralized blockchain and others are in decentralized blockchain.  Both can be transferred and use as either currency or asset depends on the belief of the holder.  And both uses cryptography to secure its network.Given the things they have in common, it is obvious altcoin and Bitcoin falls under one umbrella the cryptocurrency.Quote crypto is like fiat money, where a small group of people controls monetary policy.Another thing, other than CBDC (if this is considered a cryptocurrency) cryptocurrency can't be like fiat money in terms of issue since fiat money are issued by the government while Cryptocurrencies are not.Quote Bitcoin, on the other hand, is a far superior form of money without a central leader or group of leaders. Its users do not have to trust anyone, making it truly peer-to-peer and resistant to censorship or control.Bitcoin may be superior in terms of security but I do not think Bitcoin outperforms fiat digital transfers.  They both have advantages and disadvantage so I think whether Bitcoin is a superior form of money is debatable.  Certain issues like scaling, time confirmation, volatility, and use case is attached to Bitcoin so I think we cannot fully say that Bitcoin is far superior form of money. And decentralization might be the strongest feature of Bitcoin but it also serves as the greatest flaw of Bitcoin to those who are not fond of it, especially the centralized authority and this impedes the adoption of Bitcoin[1] https://www.investopedia.com/terms/c/cryptocurrency.asp
